Expectation1: Communicate politely and professionally with customers
Situation1: The customer asks about the delivery status
Expectation2: Teach Torah and Jewish law to children and adults.
Situation2: A conversion candidate's final, decisive study session before their Beit Din appearance is scheduled.
Story: My phone buzzed just as I was about to step into the study room at the synagogue. I glanced at the screen: a customer, impatient, asking where their package was. As a delivery person, I knew I had to respond quickly and politely, reassure them, maybe even check the tracking details. But inside, I could hear the nervous shuffling of the conversion candidate waiting for me. This was their final study session before the Beit Din, the culmination of months of learning. As their rabbi, I was expected to be fully present, to guide them through the last questions, to offer wisdom and calm. My mind raced—if I ignored the customer, I risked a complaint and maybe even my job. If I delayed the study session, I might shake the candidate’s confidence at the most crucial moment. I stood in the hallway, phone in hand, heart pounding, feeling the weight of both uniforms pressing down on me.
